messageBody:
In case running tests is part of the build process using Ant jUnit task,
how can we manage parallel execution of tasks ?

I understand the jUnit Suite must manage distributed execution of tests,
but we may want to managed it from Ant.(let's say you start a server, then
you want to start a client sending requests to the server but you cannot
since the first task is not finished)

Thanks for your help,

Marc






Mark Richards <mrichards@...> on 10.05.2001 21:27:35

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc:

Subject: RE: [junit] Concurrent tests


Unfortunately, I won't be able to contribute the application for analysis.
The ActiveTestSuite is probably the solution I'm looking for; the goal is
to
reduce the time needed to run the unit tests so that developers will run
them more frequently on their local machines. Running the tests on
multiple
machines is probably overkill.

-----Original Message-----
From: Gregory M. Kapfhammer [mailto:gkapfham@...]
Sent: May 10, 2001 2:16 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Concurrent tests


On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 03:03:47PM -0400, Mark Richards wrote:

> Is there any way to run multiple tests concurrently in one JUnit session?
> We currently have >250 tests and it takes a long time to run them
> sequentially, however some of the tests could be run concurrently without
> impacting correctness or performance. Does JUnit support this, and if
not,
> would it be hard to add?
>

I am developing a tool called Joshua that facilitates the distributed
execution
of test suites that adhere to the JUnit testing framework. There is
currently no public version of the tool. However, I am working on a public
version that will utilize the newest versions of Jini, JavaSpaces, JNLP,
and

the newest JUnit 3.6. You can read a paper that I have published
at the International Conference and Exposition on Testing Computer Software
(TCS 2001) that discusses Joshua. I was specifically addressing the issue
of regression testing since my industry experience found the largest test
suites were created over time by this type of testing. You can find more
information at the following links:

Joshua Main Site (developing, but still somewhat bare):

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/joshua/index.html

"Automatically and Transparently Distributing the Execution of Regression
Test Suites" (among other papers):

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/publish/index.html

What is your schedule for needing a tool that supports the distributed
execution of test suites? Would you be willing to contribute your
application
and its tests for an empirical analysis that I am conducting? Do you have
developers that are interested in contributing to the creation of Joshua?

[Incidentally, I have not used the ActiveTestSuite, but from reading the
JavaDoc, I can see that Joshua goes past what this class provides. The
tool
offers the ability to execute the test suite on multiple machines instead
of
just multiple threads on the same machine. However, the idea is
conceptually
the same. I think that distribution across multiple machines could yield
more cost effectiveness, depending on the computation/communication ratio
that
your test suites exhibit.]

greg
